GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Tina Chen

Class of 2019
Major/School: Biomolecular Science at the Tandon School of Engineering
Position: Freshmen Representative
Family: Socialholics

Tina is a welcome addition to the TASS freshman reps. She’s smart and hardworking, and her ability to power through ridiculously long science lab reports is second to none. But don’t let this intimidate you, because as soon as you talk with her you’ll see that she’s super fun to be around. Tina’s energetic and upbeat personality makes her a great friend and will put a smile on anyone’s face. She loves exploring the city, so come join her and the Socialholics at the next family event!

Written by Elena Kapur

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Elena Kapur

Class of 2019
Major/School: Biology at CAS
Position: Freshmen Representative
Family: Food Infatuation

Elena is an easy-going and polite girl who is great to hang around with. She is a great friend, but most importantly a great listener. She is caring and thoughtful for others. Elena is half-Taiwanese, half-Indian, and brings diversity to TASS along with a passionate love for Taiwanese food, especially Tainan food! Come join her on food hunts for delicious foods :)

Written by Tina Chen

Happy Thanksgiving from TASS! 

A few days ago, we officially came to the end of our GETTING TO KNOW YOU series! That means that all members of our eboard have a bio on our page--feel free to read up and get to know us all!

We at Tass would like to take advantage of this (American) holiday by thanking you all for spending such an amazing semester with us! We've had a lot of fun planning events for you guys and we can't wait to see you in the future!

That being said, we have a few more tricks up our sleeve this semester, so don't count us out just yet! Keep your eyes on this page for more events and announcements coming soon~ 👀
Does it come as any surprise that Taiwanese people are the most obsessed with losing weight?

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Jacqui Chen

Class of 2016 
Major: Econ CAS
Position: PR Team
Family: Night Life

The first thing that comes to mind when describing Jacqui is how good of a friend she is. Many can confirm the fact that hanging out with Jacqui makes them genuinely happy. This is something that can only be felt once you get close to her. Though many people might not be able to meet her during TASS due to her busy schedule, there is no doubt that she is dedicated and contributing in behind the scenes. 

Jacqui embodies the idea of working hard and partying even harder. Always striving to be better and trying out new things while having the most fun she can. Catch her at the next night life event, but only if you can hold your own! 

Written by Andy Chuang!

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Audrey Tseng

Class of 2017
Major/School: Studio Art
Position: Secretary 
Family: Food Infatuation 

When you meet Audrey for the first time, you’d think that she is quiet girl. That is true, but as you get to know her more, you will realize that she is actual an strong independent woman who stands up for issues she cares about. She is extremely articulate and intelligent. If you want to find someone to have a deep conversation about either the Arts, Philosophy, or just life in general, she is the person to go to.
Her best quality: Adorable loud laugh 
Her weakness: Cannot have people wear their own pants to sit on her furniture.

Written by Catherine Chou

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Alyssa Chen

Class of 2019
Major/ School: Liberal Studies
Position: Freshman Representative
Family: Food Infatuation
Alyssa, a new addition to TASS, is awesome. She’s smart and nice. More than anything, she’s very fun to be around and very approachable. Her enthusiasm and energetic and easygoing personality can turn your frown upside down. She’s a die-hard crazy fan for 宮崎駿, so if you are also into that hit her up! Into eating Taiwanese food and just an overall eating enthusiast? So is she!

Written by Mindy Hsu

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Chris Chen

Class of 2017
Major/School: Sports Management in SPS
Position: Special Events Team
Don’t be fooled by his unassuming, shy and small stature; who am I kidding - Chris is a giant in all senses of the word. Ruled by the notion of “I’M THE BEST,”’ he never fails to make his presence in the room felt, whether it is uncomfortable or not. A choir boy on the surface, comfortable while belting ballots of 21st century Divas, Chris would much rather preach the lyrical genius of Jay-Z in ‘N*ggas in Paris’. He wants to follow the footsteps of future president Kanye West: to be a modern century style icon and controversial role model. Chris already has one foot in the door, never failing to sport his signature beanie and sunglasses that scream, “I’M THE BEST.” Chris is the true renaissance man; he is smart beyond measure, athletic without compare and let’s not forget his diverse and powerful singing voice as well. He enchants everyone that is in the vicinity and always steals the show whether he is live and bopping or collapsed and passed out on the floor (because he looks good in his sleep ;)). If you need something accomplished, you can count on Chris to get it done; he is an enthusiastic and supportive friend and a great help to TASS.

Written by Wei An Lee

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Albert Liao

Class of 2018
Major/School: Steinhardt Music Business
Position: Artistic Director
Family: Nightlife
Albert is the mysterious dark horse of the TASS Board, a recent recruit with a passion for late night bondings. With an alluring smile and modelling skills, he seduces everyone around him. But behind his goofy personality and nerdy dry humor, he is a kind soul with a love for art and good food. In his free time, you can find Albert on his scooter snapping photos of the city, or smooth talking girls in WSP. Don’t be afraid to ask him out for coffee some time and be sure to ask about his new film “By Your Side - 在你身邊”.

Written by Victor Wan

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Doris Lau

Class of 2017
Major/School: Economics
Position: PR 
Family: Nightlife
Swag on swag on swag, that’s probably the first thing that comes to mind when you see Doris. She gives out that nonchalant Californian “I think life is about being chill and w/e you’re saying right now pisses me off so I continuing to chill gtfoutta my face” vibe.  As a first year E-board member on TASS, Doris gets along with everyone not just because she has been hanging out with TASS for years, but her ability to take care of business makes her a trustworthy individual that everybody needs to have in his or her life. That is also the reason why Doris is so well known among all the cultural organizations here at NYU; whenever someone needs help with anything (yes ANYTHING because Doris can most likely make it happen). Doris will be there for the rescue. That being said, don’t be surprised that you don’t get a hi back from Doris when you see her around campus. Celebrities like her rarely have time to say hi to everyone she meets.

Written by Alex Tsai

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Mindy Hsu

Class of 2019
Major/School: CAS
Position: Freshmen Representative
Family: Socialholics

This tiny jittery ball of energy is just like our very own events assistant, Monica Pan (shorties for life). Although petite (she prefers to be called “fun-sized”), she has no trouble with jumping into your face and letting you know about her day. She may be 5 feet tall but that doesn’t mean you can overpower her. Her ability to completely tear you down in a verbal argument is uncanny. Like just, don’t even try. GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Emily Chang

Class of 2019
Major/School: Liberal Studies
Position: Special Events team
Family: Socialholics

Characterized by an extremely limited vocabulary that includes such words as “very, so, and super”, she thinks everyone is “super, super, super, very, very, very, so, so NICE”, that is, except Wesley Wu, who is “very very nerdy.” Although she always claims to be fifteen minutes early to everything, her real friends know that she always runs on “Emily time”, which is at least an hour later than usual. When she finally does show up, she shows off her trademark spunkiness involving, in all honesty, the strangest hand motions anyone has ever and will ever see. Underneath her quirkiness, you will see that Emily is a great friend and person to talk to. Her incessant cheer brightens days and is a calming presence in such a fast moving world. If you see her walking around, make sure to say hello!

Written by Albert Chang

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Eric Chen

Class of 2017
Major/School: Tandon School of Engineering
Position: Events Assistant
Family: Food Infatuation
Eric goes to Tandon in Brooklyn, but that does not stop him from being committed to TASS, his friends, and all the good restaurants in Manhattan. If you visit St. Marks, you will probably run into Eric pretty often because he just loves Japanese food so much. If you really happen to see him on the street, he will show you the Eric style smile that shows exactly six teeth - well, who knows exactly how many teeth he shows when he smiles, but it’s just the perfect one that he always has. If you don’t believe how attractive he is, talk to him next time during a TASS event - you would want to eat Japanese food or play basketball so that you would have more opportunities to talk to him.

Written by Rogina Hsia

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Victor Wan

Class of 2018
Major/School: MCC in Steinhardt
Position: Events Director
Family: Food Infatuation
He likes taking basic photos of basic food because he is basic. You can never see him smile. He only wears tank tops and goes to Michelin restaurants where he continues to take basic photos of basic food. When he’s not at a Michelin restaurant, he cooks his own 5-star Michelin food. His signature apparel is Gymshark because he wants to show the world how big he really is. Remember to hit him up when you want some quality Michelin food OR if you want to eat out since he has a whole list of first class restaurants in NYC. KB.
Written by Eric Chen

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Lotus Ho

Class of 2017
Major: Psychology
Position: Special Events
Family: Socialholics

Though she may seem small and unintimidating, Lotus actually knows how to throw down and party with the best of the best. She can successfully challenge anyone to a drinking contest AND win. Between her course load, as well as TASS and her other clubs, Lotus is actually an expert on juggling time just for YOU. That’s right, underneath her cool, badass (OG NYC native) exterior, Lotus is actually warm hearted, fun loving, and just one of the perfect leaders of Tass’s Socialholics family. She’s no stranger to walking everywhere, so perhaps her next destination will be straight into your heart.

Written by Jamie Sung

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Waylan Yee

Class of 2017
Major/School: Stern
Position: Special Events Director
Family: Socialholics
This year’s token non-Taiwanese member of the board, Waylan is someone you’ll get to know as soon as you meet him. His open and eccentric personality combined with his homework jam sessions at 3AM to any music from rap and k-pop keep his friends entertained, and sometimes make you forget that #heisstern. But don’t worry, for he is in fact Stern enough to direct the Special Events team as well as manage the undisclosed budgeting for our Night Market. He enjoys his “medium” iced vanilla lattes from starbucks and bragging on snapchat about his excellent parking jobs of his luxury but nonexistent cars (or accusing others of stealing said cars from him). And after a few drinks, his rapping, dancing, and yelling at you in Korean becomes quite entertaining, as long as you can deal with his short term memory and having the same conversation over and over.

Written by Karen Chen

Hey everyone! Tass eboard here with an exciting announcement!
The eboard works really hard year round to make sure everyone in the tass community can relax and have fun at our events. But we're also a family who want to reach out and get to know everyone too! So, to help US get to know YOU, we're launching a new series to help YOU get to know US.

Starting today, we will be posting a new bio and picture of each member of eboard per day to help you recognize faces a bit quicker around each of our events! Get excited: to keep them from being boring, we've asked other eboard members to help write out the bios!

The first bios have already been selected, but let us know who you want to know a bit better and we will assist you in that process ;)

Class of 2016

NOTE TAKING TIPS - EFFECTIVE WAY TO IMPROVE ACADEMICALLY
Taking notes is an important component in every student’s plan toward getting better grades. Each key point of a lecture is a potential examination question
1. Make your own notes
The worst thing you can do is to rely on someone else to take notes on your behalf. When revising notes taken by someone else you are forced to figure out what they are trying to convey.
2. Be organized
Come up with your own way of organizing your notes. Your notes must have dates, subheadings and headings.
3. Try to understand your lecturer’s organization cues
 
Each lecturer is different. Some don’t write anything

http://www.qessays.com/news/note-taking-tips-effective-way-to-improve-academically.html

TIPS ON HOW TO SURVIVE IN COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY
Surviving in university as many of you will agree with me is not easy. It calls for wisdom to balance the energy you have and the freedom that comes with university life.  There is so much to discover, learn and enjoy while you have loads of responsibilities. Here are a few tips that will help you enjoy your life and achieve the intended objectives.
1.	Study plan
First and foremost, remember why you are there. Your main reason is to study. Your college achievements define your future.  Studying is of course demanding and calls for self discipline.  You must therefore make a study plan and come up with self motivating tactics to help you adhere to it.
2.	Plan for your meals
Though meal plans should be among your first
http://www.qessays.com/news/tips-on-how-to-survive-in-college-or-university.html

Five Tips for Starting the Semester off Right
It’s time to come back after the long holidays. Welcome back! It is normal to feel home sick, but you need to get back to the routine really fast. Here are some tips to get you started:
Understand your syllabus
Syllabus is crucial to your studies; make sure you understand it well. Once you have your class schedule set, read, print, save, frame, build a shrine, anything you need to do to have your syllabus on hand!
The easiest and fastest way to fall behind is to mess up the due dates for assignments and tests, but if you follow along with the set pace of the class, half the work is done for you. But in case you need a little more structure.
Get a planner
http://www.qessays.com/news/five-tips-for-starting-the-semester-off-right.html

There are an estimated 27+ million people in slavery today, through trafficking, child labor, and debt bondage. In fact, most of the electronics, coffee, chocolate, sugar, and cotton we buy is partially produced through slave labor. This event, as a part of Asian Heritage Month, explores the intersection of many students' Asian identities and this social justice. Specifically, through student and guest speakers (from the Nomi Network and U.S. Department of State) and discussion groups, we hope to bring together many clubs and define what modern day slavery looks like, the situation in Asia, and how we can respond to make change as students. There will also be the opportunity for students to explore the spiritual side of the issue. Dinner will be served.

Passionate about Taiwanese culture, big event planning, and e-board fun? Join the ITASA East Coast Conference Bidding Team! The application can be found at: http://tinyurl.com/nyu-itasa-ecc and will be due on November 30!

Every year, ITASA (the umbrella organization of all Taiwanese American student organizations in the U.S.) hosts a large conference on the coasts attended by more than 350 students across the nation. NYU TASS is hoping to host the East Coast Conference in Winter 2013, but we need lots of help! Here is yet another opportunity to get involved in student activities and gain tangible experience in large-scale event planning and promotion! There are nine (9) different positions to become a part of NYU ITASA Bid Board, we'd love to have all of you apply!

To learn more about ITASA East Coast Conference: Google, Youtube, or Facebook ITASA Conference! If you have further questions about the event, the board or the application, feel free to contact bid directors Angela (angelachen@nyu.edu) or Kevin (kevin.wu@stern.nyu.edu)!

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Karen Chen

Class of 2018
Major/School: LSP
Position: Special Events Team
Family: Food Infatuation

When you first meet Karen, you may be daunted by her height, but do not fear, for this coercion tactic is simply a result of the large-heeled boots that she can be heard clicking around in for a           majority of the year. Armed with these boots and perhaps a Starbucks Caramel Macchiato in one hand, iPhone in the other, Karen brings a little bit of refreshing, classic Bostonian white-girl charm to an otherwise Asian-dominated interest club. But, take the boots off, and all you’re left with is an at-first quiet girl who, in reality, is only 5’4. If you work your way to her good side, you’ll even be granted with the chance of taking a sip out of a Pumpkin Spice Latte. Even though she looks like she’s all business, Karen still has a loud side, even though the chances of finding her out of her room after 10pm are slim to none. She’s the generous type - the kind of girl who will take care of everyone else after a crazed night at a party or a bar. So chances are, if you’re been able to become her friend, she’ll always make sure you’re okay. 

Written by Waylan Yee

Magical Students Academic Tips That You Need To Succeed
A good decision on how and where to focus will help you do really well academically without overworking and stressing yourself.
Here is how;
Read and understand for information
Researchers have shown
http://www.qessays.com/news/magical-students-academic-tips-that-you-need-to-succeed.html

NOTE TAKING TIPS - EFFECTIVE WAY TO IMPROVE ACADEMICALLY
Taking notes is an important component in every student’s plan toward getting better grades. Each key point of a lecture is a potential examination question
1. Make your own notes
The worst thing you can do is to rely on someone else to take notes on your behalf. When revising notes taken by someone else you are forced to figure out what they are trying to convey.
2. Be organized
Come up with your own way of organizing your notes. Your notes must have dates, subheadings and headings.
3. Try to understand your lecturer’s organization cues
 
Each lecturer is different. Some don’t write anything

http://www.qessays.com/news/note-taking-tips-effective-way-to-improve-academically.html

Dear Taiwanese American Students of NYU:

My name is Jennifer Cohen, M.A., and I am a graduate student in the Ph.D. Clinical Psychology program at the California School of Professional Psychology at Alliant International University, Los Angeles.

I am currently recruiting participants for my doctoral dissertation, which is designed to examine stress and strength of Asian American immigrants. Participation i...s anonymous and involves the completion of online questionnaires. It will take approximately 20-25 minutes of your time. Upon completion of the study, participants may choose to enter a raffle to win one of three Visa gift cards, $50 each.

If you can please help by either posting this letter on your Facebook or sending it to people who may be qualified to be in my study, it will be greatly appreciated.

To qualify for this study, participants must an Asian American immigrant (A person of Asian descent, crossing an international border to come to United States for various reasons, excluding refugees) who meets the following three inclusion criteria:

1) Between the ages of 21 and 40 years old,
2) Residing in the U.S. between ONE and TEN years
3) Can read, write, and understand fourth grade level English

To participate in the study please go to: https://qtrial.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_b47k3e0jngDtvfe

Your participation is greatly appreciated,
Jennifer Cohen, M.A.

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Wesley Wu 

Class of 2017
Major/School: The Leonard N. Stern School of Business #iamstern
Position: Special Events Team/Tocqueville ASSet Manager
Family: Socialholics , NYU 湯匙,  “我喜歡吹喇叭"
Wesley is someone you might underestimate at first sight. From his angular jaw line up to his geometrically inspiring glasses to the perfectly trimmed hairstyle, you might think this is just another no life 4.0 GPA Asian that is going to become a doctor and marry his mother’s best friend’s daughter who is too shy to date any other guy. In fact, this kind, gentle and polite individual behaves so very very extremely professionally towards everybody he meets, that you think he is probably feeling insecure about the sad life he leads.  
Little do you know, as the sun sinks down the Hudson River and our beautiful Manhattan sky is lit up by the thousand stars, Wesley undergoes his everyday metamorphosis from a professional businessman to a professional party goer. Although he has since retired from the crazed night outs and thirst quenching journeys, legend has it that he is currently lecturing a course at NYU School of Business on “how to get some chicks tonight”.  Now days he enjoys chilling with his friends and having intellectual discussions about the future. Of course, during these “let’s talk about our future and chill” sessions Wesley won’t forget to mix in some light heartedness into the conversation. Simply put, Wesley is a guy that turns the impossible into possible. 

Written by Alex Tsai

【Teach for Taiwan為台灣而教】邀請您參與2015 Inside Day 

人在海外的你，是否願意投入兩年時間，回到台灣深入鄉間，投資自己、也投資台灣的下一代？

Teach for Taiwan (TFT) 是兩年全職教學專案計畫，招募具使命感的青年投入台灣有需求的偏鄉國小成為教師。於兩年期間，TFT 提供專業完善的培訓與支持系統，TFT 教師從中培養對教育現況的理解、獲得自我認識與成長，並於兩年後投身不同專業領域，共同成為台灣優質教育的推動者，發揮長期影響力。

Inside Day 為TFT兩年全職教學計畫的前導計畫，讓對 TFT 計畫有興趣的你，藉由 Inside Day 實際至教育現場進行完整一天的觀摩、見習，並與 TFT 在線教師深入互動及交流。凡申請 Inside Day 錄取者，可保送2016第三屆或2017第四屆TFT教師計畫之現場面試資格。

GETTING TO KNOW YOU: Wei An Lee

Class of 2019
Major/School: Sports Management in SPS
Position: Freshman Rep
Family: Nightlife

Wei An Lee…. when you first see him you might wonder… is he a freshman? But as one of our freshman rep’s this year, he’s gotta be right? He ain’t your typical freshman though… in fact… he’s not your typical anything. First off, right after high school, he joined the Singaporean army. So that dismisses your confusions, he’s a freshman, but he’s already 21 (wink wink freshman that likes to drink… water…) and he’s not even Taiwanese!~ (but he did live in Taipei for over 5 years.) But that’s not all! How many people do you know is a Hall Of Fame athlete within their high school? Throughout a young age, Wei An has always been a supreme athlete; he’s represented his country, Singapore, in sports at an International level and continues to do so even now in college. However, just because he’s so different from the usual “taiwanese guy” in TASS, don’t let that intimidate you. And definitely don’t let his usual pose of “shifting his weight side to side while both hands are in his pockets” affect your decision of approaching him to chat. He is a compassionate and capable man that you will find you enjoy spending time with. 

Written by Chris Chen

Start: Immediately
